Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mapping Changes in the Active Stream Channel Network of Mesoscale Watersheds in Order to Understand Distinct Signatures in Event Recession Curves
Award.AbstractNarration:
Water flow in watersheds is most often studied by either measuring stream flow at the watershed outlet or by making point measurements in wells within the watershed. Neither is adequate for gaining a complete picture of watershed function because measurements at the outlet can be too broad and point measurements too localized. This project seeks to fill the knowledge gap by mapping the expansion and contraction of active stream channels throughout the watershed and providing insights into which areas of a watershed are or are not contributing flow to the watershed outlet. This will provide new knowledge for better understanding how water, soil, and chemicals move through watersheds and how stream discharge will change, particularly during periods of little precipitation. As an education and outreach effort of this project, the project will develop hands-on learning opportunities for middle and high school science students and help train graduate students.

Pairs of observed rates of stream flow decline after rainfall ends (i.e. recession flow) and the concurrent stream flow value have long been used in the hydrologic sciences to infer aquifer properties at the watershed scale. However, new work has shown that spatial variation in stream flow source areas across a catchment may explain recession as well or better than aquifer property and hydraulics. Thus, there is an emerging debate on what really controls recession. Resolving this debate can provide fundamental insights into watershed function. To investigate the controls on recession, this project will install high-density sensor networks at up to six medium-sized watersheds at different locations throughout the U.S. to map changes in the extent of the active stream channel network. Sensor measurements of discharge will be supplemented with visual mapping of the active stream network, thermal imaging of likely groundwater inputs to streams, and soil moisture measurements. The project could have broader implications for predicting discharge in ungauged basins and understanding processes of solutes moving through watersheds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are thousands of gages across the U.S. where streamflow is routinely measured.  A streamflow gage can provide very direct information. For instance, at high flows, the gage can provide information on the extent of flooding. At low flows, the gage can give an indication of available water.

However, streamflow data can also offer more indirect information that can provide insights into where stream water is originating from at locations in the watershed far away from the gage itself. For instance, an ecologist may want to understand, the extent of suitable habitat for aquatic animals in small streams that are not directly gaged. Or, an aquatic chemist may want to estimate the extent of riparian areas where important chemical transformations relating to carbon or nutirents may take place This project helped develop techniques to better make use of streamflow data in order to gain knowledge on stream and watershed processes potentially happening many miles away from the gage.

Specifically, this project studied how the extent of the stream channel network changed during  periods of time after one rainfall event and before the next rainfall event. This time between rainfall events is referred to as a recession period because the streamflow declines or recedes. The study focused on using long recession periods where there are a number of days between rainfall events. Looking at a long recession event occuring after a large rainfall is likely striking a drum a single time and listening to it reverberate for an extended period. Listening to the drum after a single strike gives a different sense of its behavior versus hitting it repeatedly. Similarly, looking at watersheds during recession periods can provide information not available when looking at streamflow during a rapid succession of rainfall events.

Observations of streamflow measurements in three different watersheds in New York State provided direct evidence of how changes in the extent of actively flowing channel networks relate to stream gage streamflow data during recession. The observations indicated that the total length of the actively flowing channel network does not change as fast as streamflow decreases during individual recession events occurring over just a few days. However, over weeks to months, the active channel network will shrink in size. This contraction does not always occur in predictable ways (i.e. channels did not dry out from top to bottom). Instead, the extent of the active channel network during dry periods appeared highly dependent on underground geologic irregularities that result in springs or seeps that may sustain certain sections of streams.

While analyzing streamflow recession data cannot tell someoen exactly what section of headwater streams will and will not go dry, there are "signatures" in the data that suggest the degree of spatial irregularity. Namely, by plotting streamflow recession data in a graph, one can see shifts in the data from  recession events occuring at different times. The extent of this shifting in the graph appears to be due in part to the degree of irregularities in the watershed. This finding was supported both by direct observation as well as by computational modeling.  

Overall, this work provides a new perspective on understanding small-scale variations in processes occurring throughout a watershed while at the same time providing insight into new types of information that can be extracted from streamflow gaging data. It also offers a means to make macro-scale observations of spatial variations in watershed function. Most traditional hydrologic field measurements either make plot scale measuremenst that can be difficult to scale up or make aggregate watershed measurements that can be difficult to scale down.

Besides developing methods to better understand watershed function, this project also helped directly train a number of young scientists. In particular, six undergraduate students and one high school student gained hands-on training in data analysis and field measurement methods. Additionally, the project supported three different graduate students. One graduate student is currently finishing her degree while both others graduated and entered jobs that required expertise in hydrology.  Four of the ten total students trained or suppoted by this project were female or under-represented minorities.
